PaperTitle: Data Flow Analysis and Visualization for Spatiotemporal Statistical Data without Trajectory Information

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Loads spatiotemporal event-based statistical datasets such as GPS trajectories, Twitter data, maritime search and rescue events, and syndromic surveillance data, discarding trajectory information if present.
Inputs: Raw event-based datasets (e.g., GPS data, Twitter posts, SAR events)
Outputs: Discrete spatiotemporal event dataset without trajectory information
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section 7.1: We use GPS trajectory data and we apply our technique to the dataset after discarding the trajectory information in the data.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Represents discrete spatiotemporal event distributions as continuous functions using kernel density estimation (KDE), with Triweight kernels and variable bandwidths based on the distance to the kth nearest neighbor.
Outputs: Continuous functional representation of event density over space and time
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section 4: The bandwidth (hs;i) of the kernel (Ks) placed on the point (xi; yi) is proportional to the distance from the ith sample to the kth nearest neighbor.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Extracts potential flow maps from non-directional spatiotemporal statistical data using a gravity model, computing flow vectors by evaluating adjacent distributions over time within a 3D kernel window.
Inputs: Continuous functional representation of event density over space and time
Outputs: Spatiotemporal flow maps representing potential movement trends
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section 5.2: The spatio-temporal flow map extraction model using the gravity model is presented as follows... Equation (5).

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Extracts local flow patterns by calculating differences between functional density distributions of two time steps, producing only local movements without global flow analysis.
Inputs: Continuous functional representation of event density over two time steps
Outputs: Difference-based flow map showing local flow patterns
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section 5.2: The difference-based flow extraction model is presented as follows... Equation (6).

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Displays flow maps overlaid on a 2D geographical map to reveal movement patterns within a spatial context.
Outputs: Interactive 2D map with overlaid flow vectors and heatmaps
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section 6: The flow maps are overlaid on a map to reveal movement patterns within a geographical space and the flow fields are visualized with vector field visualization techniques.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Applies Oriented Line Integral Convolution (OLIC) to visualize directional flow patterns derived from the flow maps over the 2D map.
Outputs: OLIC overlay visualization of directional flow fields on the map
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section 6.1: Similarly, OLIC are applied only to non-zero vector fields, which are extracted in the areas whose density values are not zero.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Renders directional arrows on the flow maps to indicate vector directions and magnitudes within the spatiotemporal field.
Outputs: Arrow glyph overlay visualization of flow fields on the map
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section 6.1: Our system provides three different types of visualization including OLIC, arrow glyph, and particle visualization similar to LIC.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Implements particle advection visualization similar to Line Integral Convolution (LIC), where particles move along the vector field derived from the flow maps.
Outputs: Particle tracing overlay visualization of movement flows on the map
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section 6.1: Our system provides three different types of visualization including OLIC, arrow glyph, and particle visualization similar to LIC.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Provides a web-based client that visualizes the extracted flow maps on an interactive 3D globe with particle animations and overlays including roads, boundaries, and lakes.
Outputs: Interactive web-based flow map visualization with animated particles
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section 6.2: The web-based flow map visualization system consists of JavaScript and several APIs... the server attaches minimum geographical information including roads, country boundaries, and lakes.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Allows users to specify a region of interest on the map to focus flow extraction and visualization within that specific geographical area.
Outputs: Subset of spatiotemporal flow maps for the selected region
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section 6.1: We initially place the particles in the region of interest, such as high density or high velocity areas, using the importance-driven method proposed by BÃ¼rger et al.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Enables users to select specific time intervals to explore temporal changes in the spatiotemporal flow maps.
Outputs: Filtered spatiotemporal flow maps corresponding to selected time intervals
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section 6.1: We can extract the flow map by adjusting a0 and a1 to stress certain time steps.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Provides interactive controls for users to adjust the kernel size and gravity model parameters (a0, a1), influencing the flow map extraction process.
Outputs: Customized flow maps based on user-specified parameters
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section 5.2: Since the effects of the parameters, a0 and a1, are dominant, we use (1, 1) for a0 and a1 in order to extract the global flow patterns... however, one can extract the flow map by adjusting a0 and a1 to stress certain time steps.
